results.name: a(n) is the least number such that sigma(a(n)) is divisible by the n-th prime.
comment: Note that a(n) always exists, because sigma(2^(p-2)) = 2^(p-1)-1 is divisible by p for p>2 (by Fermat's little theorem), so there is always a candidate for a(n). Compare A227470, A272349. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, May 01 2016
link: Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
example: n=11: a(11)=16 is the least number x such that sigma(x) is divisible by the 11th prime, 31.
mathematica: Module[{nn=5000,ds},ds=DivisorSigma[1,Range[nn]];Table[Position[ds,_?(Divisible[#,n]&),1,1],{n,Prime[Range[60]]}]]//Flatten (* Much faster than the first program *) (* _Harvey P. Dale_, May 18 2018 *)
program: (MAGMA) sol:=[]; p:=PrimesUpTo(10000); for n in [1..53] do k:=2; while Max(PrimeDivisors(SumOfDivisors(k))) ne p[n] do k:=k+1; end while; sol[n]:=k; end for; sol; // _Marius A. Burtea_, Jun 05 2019
